entry.title: R sucks
entry.summary:
OK, not really. Particularly when it comes to graphics, ggplot2 is damn beautiful. The following demo shows just how powerful it is. I'll let the picture speaks for itself.

For the sake of understanding, here's the data that we'll use:

In [1]:
import pandas as pd
import pandas.rpy.common as com

df = com.load_data('iris')
df.head(10)
Out[1]:
Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species
1 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa
2 4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa
3 4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa
4 4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2 setosa
5 5.0 3.6 1.4 0.2 setosa
6 5.4 3.9 1.7 0.4 setosa
7 4.6 3.4 1.4 0.3 setosa
8 5.0 3.4 1.5 0.2 setosa
9 4.4 2.9 1.4 0.2 setosa
10 4.9 3.1 1.5 0.1 setosa
In [2]:
%load_ext rmagic
In [3]:
%%R
library(ggplot2)
p <- qplot(Sepal.Length, Petal.Length, data=iris, color=Species, size=Petal.Width, alpha=I(0.7))
print(p)

If we were to do it in matplotlib:

In [4]:
%pylab inline

Welcome to pylab, a matplotlib-based Python environment [backend: module://IPython.zmq.pylab.backend_inline].
For more information, type 'help(pylab)'.
In [5]:
scatter(df['Sepal.Length'], df['Petal.Length'], 
        c=pd.Categorical.from_array(df['Species']).labels, 
        s=df['Petal.Width'] * 50, alpha=0.7)
xlabel('Sepal length')
ylabel('Petal length')
Out[5]:
<matplotlib.text.Text at 0x10a600990>

which kinda work, but with some overhead in converting string valued variables into pandas Categorical. And we don't even have the legends yet.

entry.title: Building High Performance Computing Server in Under One Hour
entry.summary:
I finally bit the bullet and got myself an 8-core 4 GHz AMD FX-8350 gamer machine with 16 GB RAM (upgradeable up to 32 GB, which I plan to do so, someday), as I'm getting more and more serious with machine learning. I've stucked in scikit-learn out-of-memory error a couple of times, and using Amazon EC2 cluster is not always the most efficient way to go (plus the additional stress of having to look constantly at the hour…).

For doing embarassingly parallel computation stuff, such as training a Random Forest, or computing cross-validation scores for different samples/subsets of a dataset, having a lot of CPUs is clearly an advantage. scikit-learn makes it really easy to parallelize these kinds of computation (most of the time it's just a matter of setting the parameter n_jobs=-1).

So the plan is to build on this 8-core machine a computing server to which I can SSH and build my machine learning models using IPython notebook. I'll share here the steps to quickly build such a system.

Install Ubuntu server (ca. 30 min)

Because graphical desktops are gimmicks.

Download and install Anaconda Python distribution (ca. 10 min)

From here.

Configure notebook server (ca. 10 min)

Create a hashed password

Create an SSL certificate, from the command line $ openssl req -x509 -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:1024 -keyout mycert.pem -out mycert.pem

Create IPython notebook profile, from the command line $ ipython profile create nbserver

Edit the profile's configuration file

And that's it! Now SSH to the machine, cd to the folder where I'll do my analyses, and start IPython notebook server: $ ipython notebook --profile=nbserver. Then fire up the notebook from a remote web browser. The URL to use is https://[server's IP address]:[port number]. Note the https.

Using IPython makes it even easy to add more computers in the network to form a cluster using IPython.parallel. But that would be a topic for another post.

entry.title: Handwritten digit recognition
entry.summary:
I'm starting to put all my works on data analysis and machine learning on this blog. As a first real post, I thought a canonical example of machine learning task should do all right. It is actually also featured as "machine learning 101" competition on Kaggle.

I first made my submission some time ago using the code here. In the meanwhile, I think I've learnt scikit-learn a little bit more, and this post serves as an update.

The main change I implemented here is that now I included the number of PCA components in the list of parameters to be optimised. This can be achieved by using scikit-learn's Pipeline.

Another change is related to the way the dataset is partitioned to speed up the computation. We know that SVM complexity increases quadratically with sample size. With the number of hyperparameters to optimise and the cross-validation iterations to compute the algorithm performance on one parameter set, learning simply takes forever. In my previous attempt I simply partitioned the dataset into three, and trained an SVM on each partition. Each SVM is then applied to the test set, and the final prediction is obtained by majority vote.

Here I used the technique called Bootstrap aggregating (Bagging). What it does is, it takes samples from the dataset, with replacement, and uses them for training. This step produces one model/classifier. It then repeats the resampling and training a few more times to obtain more classifiers. For prediction, take a majority vote of the classifiers. This is actually the underlying mechanism of Random Forest. The difference here being that instead of decision trees, we'll used SVM as the base learners.

The advantage of using bagging is that it provides a good approximation of the input distribution, and I can subset the data over and over again without being limited by the original dataset. And since every training can take only a small subset of the original dataset, SVM can be used quite efficiently. As we'll see, bagging actually works here, in the sense that the overall classification performance is better than the best of the individual classifier.

In [1]:
# pandas and numpy
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

# scikit-learn 
from sklearn.svm import SVC
from sklearn.grid_search import GridSearchCV
from sklearn.decomposition import PCA
from sklearn.preprocessing import MinMaxScaler
from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline
from sklearn.cross_validation import Bootstrap
In [2]:
%pylab inline

Welcome to pylab, a matplotlib-based Python environment [backend: module://IPython.zmq.pylab.backend_inline].
For more information, type 'help(pylab)'.

First let's load the training data:

In [3]:
train = pd.read_csv('./data/train.csv')
train = train.astype(float64)

N = train.shape[0]

The data is a flattened 28-by-28-pixel image/matrix. So if we look at the dataset shape:

In [4]:
train.shape
Out[4]:
(42000, 785)

each row is a vector of the flattened matrix for one training example. The first column of each row stores the label (0, 1, 2, ... 9). Here we have 42000 rows / examples, which is quite a lot for my laptop.

Then let's take some random samples, and see how the original images look like:

In [5]:
f, ax = subplots(ncols=4)

imsize = (28, 28)

for axis in ax:
    row = np.random.randint(N)
    axis.matshow(np.reshape(train.iloc[row,1:], imsize), cmap='gray_r')

f.tight_layout();

Before using the SVM we need to setup a few things. First the data needs to be scaled. Here we'll use scikit-learn MinMaxScaler. We'll store the transformed features into the matrix $X$, and the training labels into the vector $y$.

Finally we'll create the PCA and SVM classifier objects.

In [6]:
min_max_scaler = MinMaxScaler()
X = min_max_scaler.fit_transform(train.iloc[:,1:])

y = train.iloc[:,0]

pca = PCA()
clf = SVC()

The pipeline of the machine learning system is shown in the figure below.

In [8]:
from IPython.display import Image
Image(filename='./images/pipeline.png')
Out[8]:

And here's the code to implement it. To specify the parameters, we just need to concatenate the name of the pipeline element and the parameter name with a __ (double underscores).

In [8]:
pipeline = Pipeline([('pca', pca), ('svc', clf)])

params = {'pca__n_components' : np.arange(20, 100, 20),
          'svc__C' : [10, 50, 100],
          'svc__gamma' : [0.1, 1e-2, 1e-3]}

clfs = []

for tr, te in Bootstrap(N, n_iter=10, train_size=0.3):
    grid_search = GridSearchCV(pipeline, params, n_jobs=-1, cv=3)
    grid_search.fit(X[tr,:], y[tr])
    clfs.append(grid_search)
    oob_score = 1./len(te) * sum( grid_search.predict(X[te,:]) == y[te] )
    print grid_search.best_params_, oob_score

{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 20, 'svc__C': 10} 0.962721088435
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 40, 'svc__C': 10} 0.963741496599
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 20, 'svc__C': 10} 0.96306122449
{'svc__gamma': 0.01, 'pca__n_components': 60, 'svc__C': 10} 0.962993197279
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 40, 'svc__C': 10} 0.966020408163
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 20, 'svc__C': 10} 0.964149659864
{'svc__gamma': 0.01, 'pca__n_components': 40, 'svc__C': 50} 0.962891156463
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 20, 'svc__C': 10} 0.963843537415
{'svc__gamma': 0.01, 'pca__n_components': 80, 'svc__C': 50} 0.965408163265
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 40, 'svc__C': 10} 0.964897959184
 0.963741496599
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 20, 'svc__C': 10} 0.96306122449
{'svc__gamma': 0.01, 'pca__n_components': 60, 'svc__C': 10} 0.962993197279
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 40, 'svc__C': 10} 0.966020408163
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 20, 'svc__C': 10} 0.964149659864
{'svc__gamma': 0.01, 'pca__n_components': 40, 'svc__C': 50} 0.962891156463
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 20, 'svc__C': 10} 0.963843537415
{'svc__gamma': 0.01, 'pca__n_components': 80, 'svc__C': 50} 0.965408163265
{'svc__gamma': 0.1, 'pca__n_components': 40, 'svc__C': 10} 0.964897959184

As we can see the individual classifier performances (i.e. classification accuracy) are between 0.963-0.966. Note that the parameter grid is not very fine-grained so there might still be room for optimisations. The reason for not including so many parameters is simple: computation time.

To produce the test set predictions, let's load the data:

In [16]:
test = pd.read_csv('./data/test.csv')
test = test.astype(float64)

Nt = test.shape[0]
In [17]:
test.shape
Out[17]:
(28000, 784)

Notice that we have one fewer column compared to the training set, this is because the test set doesn't contain any labels.

Then let's scale the test data, and store it in the matrix $X_t$:

In [19]:
Xt = min_max_scaler.transform(test)

and compute the predictions for each classifier:

In [21]:
pred = np.zeros((Nt, len(clfs)))

for i, clf in enumerate(clfs):
    pred[:,i] = clf.predict(Xt)

The final predictions are obtained as the prediction label that has the most count:

In [28]:
final_pred = [np.bincount(x).argmax() for x in pred.astype(int)]

Finally, this piece of code produces the Kaggle submission file:

In [31]:
with open('./data/submission.csv', 'w') as of:
    of.write('ImageId,Label\n')
    
    for image_id, label in enumerate(final_pred):
        of.write(str(image_id + 1) + ',' + str(label) + '\n')

The Kaggle-computed classification accuracy is 0.97014. It is not actually an improvement compared to my first submission. But looking at the classification performance of the individual classifiers, it does seem to perform somewhat better.

PS: This post is a proper IPython notebook, and thus can be downloaded from here to be executed locally. Of course the data need to be downloaded from Kaggle and saved in a "data" subdirectory.

entry.title: Hello World
entry.summary: First post!
